title: Indonesia CAR-dano: University Mobility Hub
summary: Cardano lacks presence in Indonesian universities, leaving students without real-world pathways to explore RWA, governance, and automotive-data use cases.
solution: We extend Indonesia CAR-dano v1 (Fund13) into a campus mobility RWA pipeline, using real inspection data to help Indonesian teams build practical Cardano prototypes.

sub_fields.title: Category Questions
sub_fields.description: Answer the following questions to determine the eligibility of your proposal.

sub_fields.title: Who you’re targeting, how you’ll reach them, and why this matters for Cardano?
sub_fields.description: Please provide your rationale.
sub_fields.answer:
We target students, lecturers, and early academic researchers across engineering, information systems, economics, and computer science faculties. These groups represent Indonesia’s next generation of builders and analysts who can contribute to Cardano’s research, governance discussions, and RWA development.



We reach them through direct collaboration with universities in Indonesia, academic networks, student clubs, seminar invitations, and hybrid learning sessions that allow participation from campuses outside the region.



This matters for Cardano because Indonesia is one of the largest higher-education markets in Asia, yet Cardano is nearly absent from structured academic programs. Establishing an academic hub creates a long-term pipeline of talent, research, and early builders who can strengthen Cardano’s position in emerging RWA, governance, and digital-identity studies.

sub_fields.title: Provide a list of key activities of your project:
sub_fields.description: Please provide your rationale.
sub_fields.answer:
**1\. University Roadshow Sessions**

Introductory lectures on Cardano’s architecture, governance, and RWA foundations delivered at partner campuses.



**2\. Academic Mini\-Workshop Series**

Hands-on learning modules covering wallets, governance participation, dApp exploration, and data-driven case studies.



**3\. Open Learning Materials \(Public Good\)**

Creation of curated Indonesian-language learning slides, annotated examples, and academic reading lists for Cardano.



**4\. Student Research & Thesis Support**

Guidance and references for students interested in integrating Cardano topics into research projects or final theses.



**5\. Cardano Academic Hub Report**

A consolidated report capturing attendance, insights, student feedback, and follow-up academic interest.

sub_fields.title: What are your success metrics?
sub_fields.description: Please provide your rationale.
sub_fields.answer:
1. 3+ universities engaged with at least one session each.
2. 150+ students and lecturers participating across activities.
3. 50%+ participants expressing interest in learning more or joining follow-up sessions.
4. 5–10 students beginning thesis or research exploration related to Cardano.
5. Open-access publication of all materials used in sessions.
6. Growth of a sustained academic contact network for future Catalyst or governance participation.

sub_fields.title: Please describe your proposed solution and how it addresses the problem
sub_fields.description: Please describe your proposed solution and how it addresses the problem
sub_fields.answer:
The project establishes an academic learning hub that introduces Cardano to Indonesian universities through a structured series of lectures, workshops, and open-access materials. Instead of one-off events, the hub creates a repeatable format that universities can adopt independently.



Sessions will cover Cardano’s consensus model, governance framework, staking, RWA concepts, and hands-on interactions through test environments. All materials will be openly published for reuse by lecturers and student communities, enabling long-term academic adoption beyond the project timeline.



The hub serves as a bridge between the Indonesian academic ecosystem and global Cardano discussions, helping students contribute through research, analysis, and governance participation.

sub_fields.title: Please define the positive impact your project will have on the wider Cardano community
sub_fields.description: Please define the positive impact your project will have on the wider Cardano community
sub_fields.answer:
This project establishes one of the first structured academic pathways in Indonesia that connects university talent directly to Cardano’s real-world asset (RWA) narrative. By operating inside engineering, information systems, and business faculties, the initiative turns abstract blockchain ideas into concrete learning experiences tied to data, governance, and real operational constraints. Instead of relying on general awareness campaigns, the program anchors Cardano in a credible academic environment where research, curriculum, and student work naturally compound over time.



Through three on-campus workshops and continuous academic engagement, students and faculty gain hands-on exposure to Cardano wallets, metadata structures, governance flows, and the logic behind inspection-backed RWA models. These interactions create a talent pipeline that feeds future builders, researchers, and contributors into the wider ecosystem. All materials including slides, governance guides, student research starters, and lecture recordings are published openly, enabling reuse across Indonesia and by universities in other regions.



**Key areas of positive impact include:**

**1\. Long\-term academic anchoring**

Cardano becomes a reference platform for coursework, research topics, technical demos, and student innovation projects.



**2\. Structured onboarding for new technical talent**

Hundreds of students gain practical exposure to Cardano fundamentals tied to real economic activity, not purely theoretical blockchain content.



**3\. Open\-access educational assets for global reuse**

Universities and communities can replicate the same workshops, lecture flow, and governance materials without new development costs.



**4\. Strengthening Cardano’s RWA legitimacy**

Demonstrating how mobility data and inspection logic can be studied academically reinforces Cardano’s position as a platform suitable for real-world systems.



**5\. Regional ecosystem growth**

Connecting Indonesia’s university ecosystem (one of the largest in Southeast Asia) to Cardano increases visibility, diversity of contributors, and future project pipelines.

sub_fields.title: What is your capability to deliver your project with high levels of trust and accountability? How do you intend to validate if your approach is feasible?
sub_fields.description: What is your capability to deliver your project with high levels of trust and accountability? How do you intend to validate if your approach is feasible?
sub_fields.answer:
The team has a strong delivery record in the Cardano ecosystem. We previously completed the Indonesia CAR-dano project under Fund13, producing on-chain inspection reports and meeting all reporting requirements. This gives us practical experience delivering Catalyst milestones and managing a project end-to-end with full transparency.

For this academic program, we work directly with Universitas Gadjah Mada (UGM). Faculty members from the engineering and information systems departments are involved as academic advisors and hosts for the workshops. Their participation ensures that the content fits university standards and connects with existing research interests around mobility data, inspection systems, and digital trust.

Operationally, the project materials, datasets, governance guides, and demo flows are prepared in advance with the help of UGM and delivered through scheduled on-campus sessions. No new protocol development is required; the workshops rely on existing wallets, governance tools, and metadata templates, which minimizes technical risk.

Feasibility is validated through clear procedures such as formal campus confirmations, attendance records, feedback surveys, workshop documentation, and open publication of all teaching materials. Because the team has already executed a funded Catalyst project and is backed by an established university partner, the program has a predictable delivery path and a low execution risk.

sub_fields.title: Milestone Title
sub_fields.description: A clear, concise title for this milestone
sub_fields.answer: Academic Partnership & Curriculum Setup

sub_fields.title: Milestone Outputs
sub_fields.description: What will be delivered in this milestone
sub_fields.answer:
This milestone establishes all academic groundwork needed to run the university program across the selected campuses.



**1\. Curriculum & Session Materials \(ID/EN\)**

Slide decks, lecture notes, workshop flow, research starter-pack, and governance intro modules.

**2\. Academic Collaboration Pack**

Template agreements, email scripts, faculty briefing notes, and student club onboarding material.

**3\. Documentation Framework**

Standardized attendance sheet, survey form, photo/video documentation checklist.

**4\. Internal Dry\-Run of Sessions**

Internal test delivery of the 45–60 min lecture and 60–90 min workshop before going to universities.

sub_fields.title: Acceptance Criteria
sub_fields.description: Specific conditions that must be met
sub_fields.answer:
1. Curriculum v1.0 published in shared drive with proper versioning.
2. Signed confirmations from 3 universities (email confirmation acceptable for Milestone 1).
3. All session materials pass internal review for clarity and academic suitability.
4. Internal dry-run completed and evaluated (content, timing, Q&A flow).

sub_fields.title: Evidence of Completion
sub_fields.description: How you will demonstrate achievement
sub_fields.answer:
1. Shared drive link to curriculum, slides, and templates.
2. Screenshots or PDFs of university confirmations.
3. Internal dry-run log + evaluation notes.
4. Uploaded academic pack documents (scripts, templates, briefing notes).

sub_fields.title: Please provide a cost breakdown of the proposed work and resources
sub_fields.description: Please provide a cost breakdown of the proposed work and resources
sub_fields.answer:
**1\. University Events Delivery – 45% \(6,750 ADA\)**

Covers the execution of three on-campus Cardano mobility workshops, including:

1. Venue reservation and campus coordination
2. Transportation for speakers and support staff
3. Participant kits (handouts, printed materials, certificates)
4. Presenter honoraria
5. On-site assistants (registration, logistics)
6. Audio-visual documentation for open-access reports



**2\. Academic Content & Curriculum Production – 20% \(3,000 ADA\)**

Supports development of structured and reusable learning materials:

1. Lecture slide decks (ID/EN)
2. Governance onboarding scripts
3. Student research starter packs
4. Short educational video clips
5. Graphic assets and infographics for academic use



**3\. University Outreach & Network Building – 15% \(2,250 ADA\)**

Ensures active engagement with faculties, student clubs, and research groups:

1. Coordination with 3 universities (MoUs, approvals)
2. Faculty liaison and academic briefings
3. Promotion within campus networks
4. Travel for pre-event meetings
5. Digital channels for ongoing student communication



**4\. Reporting & Open Access Publication – 10% \(1,500 ADA\)**

Covers documentation and global sharing of all academic outputs:

1. Three event reports (ID/EN)
2. Consolidated final report
3. Open-source repository for all materials
4. Publishing lecture recordings and workshop recaps
5. Dataset preparation for governance insight



**5\. Project Management – 10% \(1,500 ADA\)**

Includes administrative oversight, scheduling, milestone reporting, and compliance:

1. Coordination with Catalyst
2. Budget stewardship
3. Milestone planning and verification
4. Quality control for all academic outputs
5. Risk management and contingency handling

sub_fields.title: How does the cost of the project represent value for the Cardano ecosystem?
sub_fields.description: How does the cost of the project represent value for the Cardano ecosystem?
sub_fields.answer:
**1\. Direct academic impact, not speculative**

Every activity converts funding into measurable learning outcomes: lectures delivered, workshops executed, and students onboarded into governance.

**2\. Low\-cost, high\-volume engagement**

Three on-campus events reach 150+ students and faculty at a fraction of typical university outreach cost, maximizing ADA efficiency.

**3\. Reusable academic assets**

All lecture decks, workshop modules, research kits, and templates are open-access, enabling replication across Indonesian and global universities.

**4\. Strengthening governance participation**

Students and lecturers gain practical, guided exposure to Cardano governance flows, increasing informed voter participation and DRep engagement.

**5\. Scalable academic model**

The structure (curriculum, scripts, templates) allows any student club or faculty to run follow-up sessions without new infrastructure.

**6\. Ecosystem\-aligned and regionally strategic**

The program expands Cardano Open: Ecosystem through grassroots education, building long-term talent pipelines in one of the world’s largest higher-education markets.
